subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: New Zealand has committed to separate domestic and international carbon reduction targets. It has committed to a domestic target of net-zero greenhouse gas emissions (excluding biogenic methane) by 2050.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Internationally, it has committed a Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) – its official plan to cut emissions under the Paris Agreement − of reaching 30% below 2005 level emissions by 2030. New Zealand is currently formulating a raft of policies and frameworks to decarbonize its energy system beyond its already heavily decarbonized power market.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: There is no fossil fuel phase-out policy in New Zealand.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: New Zealand has a robust and transparent power market, operated on a wholesale dispatch basis. While there are no major barriers for market entry for new players or capacity, sufficient supply and limited demand growth have kept recent new additions low. The New Zealand power system is already heavily decarbonized by international standards, owing to significant hydropower capacity. The government aims to have 90% of electricity generation supplied by renewable energy sources by 2025 (in an average hydrological year).

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Despite relatively high retail power prices, uptake of behind-the-meter technologies like rooftop solar remains comparatively low due to relatively poor economics and a lack of government subsidies for new technologies.

subsections.title: Power market
text: Most areas of NZ have are fully liberalized with many potential electricity providers.
Private investment is able to enter all sections of the NZ power market except transmission, which is responsibility of Transpower since 1994.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Grid connection rules procedures are highly transparent.

subsections.title: EV market
text: New Zealand has fostered a burgeoning low- or no-emissions vehicle fleet, implementing road user charge exemptions and policies supporting the development of electric vehicle (EV) infrastructure. It has relied heavily on imported second-hand electric vehicles to grow its EV fleet.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: Recently, New Zealand implemented an emissions standard for imported new or second-hand vehicles, as well as a rebate program for low- or no-emissions cars. These new programs could drive significant new uptake in EVs over the near term, reducing emissions in line with the government’s carbon reduction targets.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The government has yet to implement any substantial policy support in this sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: Residential heating in New Zealand is dominated by direct electric heating and heat pumps. Heat pump sales have seen an average annual growth of around 10% of 2010 to 2020. The increased uptake of heat pumps has improved energy efficiency of homes, as heat pumps use less electricity to produce the same amount of heat as direct electric heating.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: The “Warmer Kiwi Homes” program offers support in the form of grants for low-income households. The scheme supports improvements for insulation and installation of heat pumps. A public consultation for the proposed new Building for Climate Change Program was during 2020. If this legal proposal is adopted, it would enforce a mandatory reporting framework for building’s emissions during construction and operation.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in buildings, although it intends to release detailed policy plans in its future Building for Climate Change Programme.
